abstract.p: Lower Manhattan Cultural Council to offer 16-day free festival of music, dance and theater; amateur pianists from around world to vie in Van Cliburn Foundation competition, Fort Worth, Tex; Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, Williamstown, Mass, plans exhibition on American depictions of Orient, 1870-1930; Newport International Film Festival is set for Newport, RI; photos (M)

block.p: Opening night will feature the Garth Fagan Dance Company; coming attractions include the Eos Orchestra playing Holst's ''Planets'' on June 21, Spalding Gray in ''Interview With the Audience'' on June 22 and Lenny Pickett in a jazz retrospective on June 24. Beginning tomorrow, the attraction is ''Evening Stars,'' a 16-day free festival of music, dance and theater presented by the Lower Manhattan Cultural Council on the World Trade Center Plaza. The festivities, except for Jazz Festival performances from 1 to 8 p.m. on Saturday and Sunday, begin each evening at 7. Information: (212) 435-6600.

Among the contestants are a microbiologist, a midwife, a news anchor, a tennis coach, a flight attendant, a lawyer and a bank executive. Who will win? Not even the astrologer from London can be sure. Like the others, she is among the 75 people from around the world who begin vying today in the Van Cliburn Foundation's Second International Piano Competition for Outstanding Amateurs at the Ed Landreth Auditorium on the campus of Texas Christian University in Fort Worth. Selected by a panel of judges after 30-minute recitals by the six finalists on Saturday, the winner receives $2,000. Information: (817) 738-6536.

Beginning in the mid-19th century, artists like Frederic Edwin Church, John Singer Sargent, William Merritt Chase and Elihu Vedder turned to depictions of what they called the Orient. And with the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago in 1893, Orientalism blossomed in American advertising and popular culture. Beginning on Sunday at the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute in Williamstown, Mass., images of the harem, hookah smokers, spice merchants and turbaned warriors will be seen among the approximately 100 paintings, works of decorative art, music sheets, advertisements, Shriner memorabilia, photographs, fashions and film clips assembled through Sept. 4 in ''Noble Dreams, Wicked Pleasures: Orientalism in America, 1870-1930.'' Information: (413) 458-2303.

With Kenneth Branagh on hand to introduce his new Miramax film, ''Love's Labour's Lost,'' in its East Coast premiere prior to a gala reception at Ochre Court on Millionaires' Point, the third annual Newport International Film Festival gets under way tomorrow night in Newport, R.I. Before the event ends on Sunday, it will offer one United States, three North American and three world premieres, with 12 countries in a competition that includes 10 features, 10 documentaries and 24 short films. Among other festival events are a jazz film series and an outdoor screening of ''Young Frankenstein.'' Information: (401) 848-9443.
